Award.AwardTitle: 12th International Symposium on Functional p-Electron Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL AND NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

In July 2015, the University of Washington will be hosting the 12th International Symposium on Functional pi-Electron Systems. This is an international meeting that is held every two years and focuses on the latest developments in the area of organic semiconducting materials. Organic semiconducting materials are an exciting class of materials with applications in the area of flexible electronic devices with the potential of being embedded into textiles or used in tactile sensors or electronic skin. They are already being used as the active material in a number of commercially available electronic devices such as organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) in cellphone displays. More recently, much effort has been put forth towards developing organic semiconducting materials for use in flexible organic photovoltaics (OPVs). Flexible OPVs represent a unique opportunity in renewable energy where organic semiconducting materials can afford high power-generation-to-weight ratios that will simultaneously reduce the module, installation, and transportation costs associated with these devices. Furthermore, there is increasing interest in the area of bioelectronics to enable electronic devices that can directly communicate with our bodies.

There are three primary goals for this conference: (i) Provide a forum where scientists who work in this area of research can share their latest results with each other to accelerate mutual knowledge, progress in the field, and international collaborations; (ii) To make sure that the US remains a leader in the area of organic semiconducting materials by hosting this conference that has not been held in the US in six years, and in this way also to enable US students and other attendees to obtain the latest knowledge in this field; (iii) To increase diversity of the scientists who work in this area of research, and enhance participation of women and underrepresented minorities and their inclusion among invited speakers in the conference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Fπ conferences initially began as the “International Symposium on Functional Dyes” in Osaka in 1989. This was a watershed event that stimulated a sense of optimism that organic electronic materials would have a significant impact on the field of photonics and electronic devices. Since then, the Fπ conferences have been held all over the world rotating between Asia, Europe and USA (Japan (Osaka in 1989, 1999, and 2006 and Kobe in 1992), USA (Santa Cruz in 1995, Ithaca in 2004, Atlanta in 2009), Europe (Ulm, Germany, in 2002, Graz, Austria, in 2008 and Arcachon, France in 2013), and China (Beijing, in 2011)). In order to broaden the scope of the conference and to adjust to developments in academic and industrial research, the name was changed to the “International Symposium on Functional π-Electron Systems” in 2002. In 2015, the 12th International Symposium on Functional π-Electron Systems (Fπ-12) was held at the University of Washington, Seattle.

Fπ-12 aimed to build upon the successes of the previous Fπ conferences and attracted 370 participants from all over the world to discuss their new achievements in research fields including:

  • design and synthesis of new π-conjugated molecules and polymers
  • organic and polymeric semiconducting materials for thin film transistors
  • organic and polymeric photovoltaic and photo-detective materials and devices
  • organic light-emitting materials for display and lighting application
  • hybrid/perovskite materials and devices
  • conjugated polymers and oligomers in chemo/bio-sensors
  • bioelectronics

The field of organic electronics has grown exponentially over the past couple of decades and we have now reached a stage where the external quantum efficiency (EQE) of organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs) outperform those of inorganic LEDs, the charge mobility of organic π-conjugated semiconducting polymers easily surpass that of amorphous Si, and organic photovoltaics (OPVs) have reached power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) >10%. While organic electronic materials has had major impact in a number of applications, new areas are still being forged. For example, bioelectronics is a growing new field and interest in hybrid organic-inorganic materials (eg. perovskites based PVs).

Fπ-12 was an opportune moment to bring together leading practitioners in this and closely related fields to compare notes, assess the current state-of-the-art of these technologies, identify major obstacles to commercial deployment, and brainstorm about what the future might hold. This was also an opportune moment for the US to host this conference. The meeting had not been held in the US in five years, and it was essential that researchers in the US remain world leaders in the area of organic electronics. To this end, the Committee tried to structure the meeting so that a complementary group of investigators from related fields could spend time sharing their results and stimulate each other to think creatively about how to exploit these major advances and how to overcome the obstacles that stand in the way of even more dramatic advances.

Another major goal of the meeting was to ensure that researchers from underrepresented groups were included in the program. Fπ-12 was the first time that we had not just one but two women being Chairs of the Conference. 3 out of the 9 plenary speakers were women. Out of the 10 invited speakers from the US, 3 were URMs.
